title: Secrets Behind Monopoly Goâ€™s Record-Breaking Launch with Ben Webley, CMO of Scopely

rawLines.text: This is the kickoff of MAU Vegas 2025.
I'm Jen Dano. I host Deconstructor of
Fun. Uh we are a game industry podcast
and I'm also a reform big company game
industry marketer. Uh Monopoly Go,
that's the reason we're here today, is
the mobile game that has broken records
and rules. And I'm thrilled to speak
with Scoply CMO Ben Webb. Uh we're going
to go behind the scenes and unpack a lot
of what made the go to market so
amazing. So before we jump in, let me
just set a little bit of the game board
uh with a little background on Monopoly
Go. So Monopoly Go launched back in
April of 2023 and it broke a ton of
records. It was the number one game
launch of that year. It reached a
billion in revenue just seven months
later. It was one of the fastest mobile
games to ever reach this milestone. Fast
forward and Monopoly Go is still
crushing it. They just announced passing
five billion in revenue in just two
years. One of the things that I learned
from Monopoly that I've been really
impressed with is that uh they have such
global awareness and you know what's
really interesting is most people think
that Monopoly is from their own country.
So how did you think about leveraging
this kind of insight that is really
unique for an IP which is everyone
thinks that the IP is from their
country.
Yeah. So, I've got quite an interesting
story, actually, and it's embarrassing
one for me, but here we go. And I was in
a meeting with Hasbro and a bunch of
Hasbro executives, and uh they were
talking about playing Monopoly growing
up. And I I was really confused and I
asked them, I was like, "You guys played
Monopoly growing up?" And they're like,
"Well, yeah." And I was like, "Oh,
that's weird." And they were like, "Why
is that weird?" I was like, "Well, it's
a British game. I just didn't think that
would be that popular in America." And
um so obviously after being laughed at
for a while uh one one of the executives
actually said to me well to be honest he
said what's really interesting with this
brand is that people actually think it's
their own game in their own country. He
said in France they think it's French
and in UK they think it's British and
and that's what's so great about this
brand everyone thinks it's their their
local game. You know I I I think I I
hear a lot of people talk about Monopoly
as global IP. And I I just it didn't
resonate with me and I I thought that
wasn't the right way for us to think
about it. So instead what I asked the
team to think about and and for myself
as well is I was like I think we need
this isn't a global IP. That's the wrong
way to think about this is everybody's
local IP. You know we work with a lot of
IP at Scopely and it's really important
when you work with IP to be very
respectful to the IP to be very
authentic to the IP and uh and I wanted
to do that with Monopoly. Um so instead
of just localizing the creative we went
to the level of truly culturalizing the
creative. So, I wanted to make sure that
the creatives themselves were truly
culturalized because I wanted to give
everybody their game and bring that
nostalgia and make it feel like the
monopoly they they knew and love. So, um
it was a lot more work. I won't lie. We
created thousands and thousands of
creators because we were trying to do
that in as many countries as possible.
Uh but I think it paid off and I think
it was so important. Um and we wanted to
win in every country. We did. We um we
got to number one over 100 countries
which we're very proud of. We had um a
strategy we called uh leave no country
behind because we just didn't want to to
sort of leave countries out. We wanted
every country to get their version of
monopoly and and we we we were playing a
win and we wanted to win in every
country. We also have a philosophy um at
Scopely and that's we try and break our
own ideas and I think this is important
both for product and for marketing and
what we mean by breaking our own ideas
is I think as humans like human nature
is when we come up with a good idea we
seek out the information and the data
that supports that idea right and and I
think we'll do it and I think it's very
natural to do and one of the things we
try and do um be it and and I'll walk
through this example with the app app
icon in a minute, but is we try and
challenge our ideas not by not just
looking for other information but
actually looking for information that
basically makes our idea wrong that that
breaks it right in the way we look at it
is if you try and break your ideas
enough and they just don't break then
they are good ideas. If they break
easily it's not a good idea and you
should really rethink about that. Here's
an example of app icon testing. Now this
is doing a disservice to the number of
app icons we actually tested. We created
a lot. So the first thing we did is we
put out a bunch of different icons,
right? And you can see in the first
test, again, there were a lot more than
this. These are just some samples of
things that we thought are going to
resonate. Now, I care about every little
tiny part of the funnel. So app icon,
it's important to me.
The number one thing.
Yeah, it's important. This is important
as a creative. Yeah, as a description.
Every part of the funnel can be
optimized. So we should optimize every
part of the funnel. So with the app
icons, you know, we asked the team,
okay, let's go and test a bunch of
stuff. We did um player insights testing
as well as ASO testing. But if you see
the uh the green box around the top left
icon in test one, that's actually the
one you see today. So that was the the
winning creative. But after we did the
first test, rather than stopping there,
but also rather than saying, "Oh, that's
probably the best icon. Let's just
check." Instead, we said, "No, no, no.
We don't like it. We want to find a
better icon." Like, "Let's break that
icon. Let's make let's find there's got
to be something better. Let's go and
find something better." And the
difference, I think, in doing that is
your mindset's different, right? if
you're trying to just say it's probably
the best one. Let's do some other tests.
You're not really trying to break it,
right? You're not really putting the
effort in. So, we really tried to find
something better. In fact, I didn't tell
my team I liked the icon. I actually
told them I didn't like it and I wanted
a different one. And um so I was like,
let's go find something else. That's not
good enough. Let's find something else.
But the whole point is we just kept
trying to break it. Trying to break
trying to break it.
Well, one of the things that's
interesting and I was having this
conversation with someone recently is
notice that it's red and um so in my
prior world, I made a lot of toys. um
you know power all these different toy
brands and what I always found is that
red packaging tended to do the best
because it's a hot color whereas blue
and some of the lighter colors are cool
colors and so you feel more calm red is
more attention getting red or yellow are
hot colors and so and pro tip is always
make sure that you are testing cool
versus hot and understand you know red
does kind of that's why red and yellow
tend to be the most popular uh ASO
backgrounds. Uh free free tip for
everyone uh going into that.
Cool. All right. So, you broke it and
then um you know, let's talk a little
bit about like how people actually break
each other playing this. I don't know
how many of you like fought with your
family every holiday playing Monopoly.
But it is a timeless game that has two
kind of core aspects or key aspects to
the core fantasy. So, one is you're
making alliances and then you're
breaking them. The game features
actually leverage this incredibly well.
But how did you take that core fantasy
of like alliances and breaking alliances
and really look at that from a community
and a a social perspective to really
think about the verality from a
marketing perspective?
Yeah. I I mean if again if you've played
Monopoly Go you realize this game's a
lot more fun and rewarding playing with
others, right? And that's by design.
This game is really designed to play
with others. One that's very true to
Monopoly, right? It is a game where
you're you're playing you're playing
with people you love, but you're also
attacking them and taking all their
money, right? So, we want to capture a
lot of that in in the game. A big part
of this game is the the sticker trading.
So, there's, you know, you're attacking
each other. You're doing co-op events
together. The meta around this game
trading is very very popular. It gives a
sort of larger purpose to why you're
doing the core loop every day. We made a
very conscious decision in the product
to not build the trading into the
product, which sounds counterintuitive
because it'd be nice and easy if you and
I can trade and click the button, right?
Be very easy. But one one of the things
is we really care about building
hyperengaged communities at Scopely and
you know we believe a lot of the biggest
and best games have that they have huge
communities around them that live and
exist outside the product. Um so we
wanted to kind of meet communities where
they are and develop communities outside
the product and we wanted trading to be
a way communities engage with each other
and not just a transaction. So instead
what we did is we pushed the trading to
Facebook. We have about just over 9
million people in our core group today.
Um, and we figured if we push on to
Facebook there, they can meet people,
they can interact, they can trade. Um,
and and and it's more of a community
platform. Then we thought about, well,
how can we leverage though this really
engaged big population of people to help
sort of, you know, drive awareness and
and promotion. So, one of the things we
did is I was like, we need to get them
to Tik Tok. So, we had this place now
where we could talk to our really
engaged community members. We did more
things like that where we're moving
people onto Tik Tok onto Insta where we
could then get things going where again
those channels themselves are going to
show the game to new people and that's
what I wanted. So again like these these
whole community groups they're not only
great for building community around the
product they can actually be leveraged
and used in a way that helps us drive
more reality and organic growth for the
product as well.
So back in November you actually
launched a brand campaign uh it's called
friendship pays and so this had Will
Ferrell as Mr. Monopoly. It also had
Chris Pratt, Kiki Palmer, and then the
best hair guy of all time, Jason Mamoa.
So, in this campaign, you know, everyone
knows that friendship is is a part of
this, even though it's also about, you
know, breaking alliances. So, there's
often this tension that happens between
performance marketing and brand
marketing. I know all of you feel it.
Um, so, but you were crushing it in your
way. Absolutely winning. How did you
think about and conceptualizing? Okay,
now we want to do a brand campaign.
Yeah. So we actually see this we don't
really think of brand campaigns. We
think more around how do we extend what
we're already doing and we think of it
more 360. So um I mean first of all you
know we didn't do this campaign for
about 18 months after launch. I'm a big
believer for launch community creative
and UA do so much heavy lifting. So
think 360 everything influencers TV
connected TV UA it all worked together
and was all part of the campaign. We
actually saw this as this is going to be
like this thing that's going to last
over a year and we're going to build
creative in a way that benefits UA, it
benefits uh a social and Tik Tok and we
actually recorded and by the way Jason
wonderful guy has great hair. Um but
they were a lot of fun. So we were
trying to get things even with them
authentically to record you know some
things they were doing where they're
talking to the camera and they're
messing around cuz we're like that's not
good for TV that's fantastic for Tik
Tok.
Thank you for sharing the secrets and
and thank you to the marketing team
behind this. Um, you know, they often
don't get all the credit. The game team
gets a lot of the credit. So, I'm glad
that we had a chance to hear a little
bit more of of the story.
Awesome. Cool. Thanks for having me.

cleanText:
This is the kickoff of MAU Vegas 2025.
I'm Jen Donahoe.
I host Deconstructor of Fun.
Uh, we are a game industry podcast, and I'm also a reform big company game industry marketer.
Uh, Monopoly GO!, that's the reason we're here today, is the mobile game that has broken records and rules.
And I'm thrilled to speak with Scopely CMO Ben Webley.
Uh, we're going to go behind the scenes and unpack a lot of what made the go-to-market so amazing.
So before we jump in, let me just set a little bit of the game board, uh, with a little background on Monopoly GO!.
So Monopoly GO! launched back in April of 2023, and it broke a ton of records.
It was the number one game launch of that year.
It reached a billion in revenue just seven months later.
It was one of the fastest mobile games to ever reach this milestone.
Fast forward, and Monopoly GO! is still crushing it.
They just announced passing five billion in revenue in just two years.
One of the things that I learned from Monopoly that I've been really impressed with is that, uh, they have such global awareness, and you know what's really interesting is most people think that Monopoly is from their own country.
So how did you think about leveraging this kind of insight that is really unique for an IP, which is everyone thinks that the IP is from their country?
Yeah.
So, I've got quite an interesting story, actually, and it's embarrassing one for me, but here we go.
And I was in a meeting with Hasbro and a bunch of Hasbro executives, and, uh, they were talking about playing Monopoly growing up.
And I, I was really confused, and I asked them, I was like, "You guys played Monopoly growing up?"
And they're like, "Well, yeah."
And I was like, "Oh, that's weird."
And they were like, "Why is that weird?"
I was like, "Well, it's a British game.
I just didn't think that would be that popular in America."
And, um, so obviously after being laughed at for a while, uh, one, one of the executives actually said to me, well, to be honest, he said, "What's really interesting with this brand is that people actually think it's their own game in their own country.
He said, "In France, they think it's French, and in UK, they think it's British, and and that's what's so great about this brand.
Everyone thinks it's their, their local game."
You know, I, I, I think I hear a lot of people talk about Monopoly as global IP.
And I, I just, it didn't resonate with me, and I, I thought that wasn't the right way for us to think about it.
So instead, what I asked the team to think about, and and for myself as well, is I was like, "I think we need, this isn't a global IP.
That's the wrong way to think about this.
It's everybody's local IP."
You know, we work with a lot of IP at Scopely, and it's really important when you work with IP to be very respectful to the IP, to be very authentic to the IP, and, uh, and I wanted to do that with Monopoly.
Um, so instead of just localizing the creative, we went to the level of truly culturalizing the creative.
So, I wanted to make sure that the creatives themselves were truly culturalized because I wanted to give everybody their game and bring that nostalgia and make it feel like the monopoly they they knew and love.
So, um, it was a lot more work.
I won't lie.
We created thousands and thousands of creators because we were trying to do that in as many countries as possible.
Uh, but I think it paid off, and I think it was so important.
Um, and we wanted to win in every country.
We did.
We, um, we got to number one over 100 countries, which we're very proud of.
We had, um, a strategy we called, uh, "leave no country behind" because we just didn't want to, to sort of leave countries out.
We wanted every country to get their version of monopoly, and and we, we, we were playing a win, and we wanted to win in every country.
We also have a philosophy, um, at Scopely, and that's we try and break our own ideas, and I think this is important both for product and for marketing.
And what we mean by breaking our own ideas is, I think, as humans, like human nature is, when we come up with a good idea, we seek out the information and the data that supports that idea, right?
And and I think we'll do it, and I think it's very natural to do.
And one of the things we try and do, um, be it, and and I'll walk through this example with the app app icon in a minute, but is we try and challenge our ideas, not by not just looking for other information, but actually looking for information that basically makes our idea wrong, that that breaks it, right?
In the way we look at it is, if you try and break your ideas enough and they just don't break, then they are good ideas.
If they break easily, it's not a good idea, and you should really rethink about that.
Here's an example of app icon testing.
Now this is doing a disservice to the number of app icons we actually tested.
We created a lot.
So the first thing we did is we put out a bunch of different icons, right?
And you can see in the first test, again, there were a lot more than this.
These are just some samples of things that we thought are going to resonate.
Now, I care about every little tiny part of the funnel.
So app icon, it's important to me.
The number one thing.
Yeah, it's important.
This is important as a creative.
Yeah, as a description.
Every part of the funnel can be optimized.
So we should optimize every part of the funnel.
So with the app icons, you know, we asked the team, okay, let's go and test a bunch of stuff.
We did, um, player insights testing as well as ASO testing.
But if you see the, uh, the green box around the top left icon in test one, that's actually the one you see today.
So that was the the winning creative.
But after we did the first test, rather than stopping there, but also rather than saying, "Oh, that's probably the best icon.
Let's just check."
Instead, we said, "No, no, no.
We don't like it.
We want to find a better icon."
Like, "Let's break that icon.
Let's make, let's find, there's got to be something better.
Let's go and find something better."
And the difference, I think, in doing that is your mindset's different, right?
If you're trying to just say it's probably the best one.
Let's do some other tests.
You're not really trying to break it, right?
You're not really putting the effort in.
So, we really tried to find something better.
In fact, I didn't tell my team I liked the icon.
I actually told them I didn't like it, and I wanted a different one.
And, um, so I was like, "Let's go find something else.
That's not good enough.
Let's find something else."
But the whole point is we just kept trying to break it.
Trying to break, trying to break it.
Well, one of the things that's interesting, and I was having this conversation with someone recently, is notice that it's red, and, um, so in my prior world, I made a lot of toys.
Um, you know, power all these different toy brands, and what I always found is that red packaging tended to do the best because it's a hot color, whereas blue and some of the lighter colors are cool colors, and so you feel more calm.
Red is more attention getting.
Red or yellow are hot colors, and so, and pro tip is always make sure that you are testing cool versus hot and understand, you know, red does kind of, that's why red and yellow tend to be the most popular, uh, ASO backgrounds.
Uh, free, free tip for everyone, uh, going into that.
Cool.
All right.
So, you broke it, and then, um, you know, let's talk a little bit about like how people actually break each other playing this.
I don't know how many of you like fought with your family every holiday playing Monopoly.
But it is a timeless game that has two kind of core aspects or key aspects to the core fantasy.
So, one is you're making alliances, and then you're breaking them.
The game features actually leverage this incredibly well.
But how did you take that core fantasy of like alliances and breaking alliances and really look at that from a community and a, a social perspective to really think about the verality from a marketing perspective?
Yeah.
I, I mean, if again, if you've played Monopoly GO!, you realize this game's a lot more fun and rewarding playing with others, right?
And that's by design.
This game is really designed to play with others.
One, that's very true to Monopoly, right?
It is a game where you're, you're playing, you're playing with people you love, but you're also attacking them and taking all their money, right?
So, we want to capture a lot of that in in the game.
A big part of this game is the the sticker trading.
So, there's, you know, you're attacking each other.
You're doing co-op events together.
The meta around this game trading is very, very popular.
It gives a sort of larger purpose to why you're doing the core loop every day.
We made a very conscious decision in the product to not build the trading into the product, which sounds counterintuitive because it'd be nice and easy if you and I can trade and click the button, right?
Be very easy.
But one, one of the things is we really care about building hyperengaged communities at Scopely, and you know, we believe a lot of the biggest and best games have that, they have huge communities around them that live and exist outside the product.
Um, so we wanted to kind of meet communities where they are and develop communities outside the product, and we wanted trading to be a way communities engage with each other and not just a transaction.
So instead, what we did is we pushed the trading to Facebook.
We have about just over 9 million people in our core group today.
Um, and we figured if we push on to Facebook there, they can meet people, they can interact, they can trade.
Um, and and and it's more of a community platform.
Then we thought about, well, how can we leverage though this really engaged big population of people to help sort of, you know, drive awareness and and promotion.
So, one of the things we did is I was like, we need to get them to Tik Tok.
So, we had this place now where we could talk to our really engaged community members.
We did more things like that where we're moving people onto Tik Tok, onto Insta, where we could then get things going where again, those channels themselves are going to show the game to new people, and that's what I wanted.
So again, like these, these whole community groups, they're not only great for building community around the product, they can actually be leveraged and used in a way that helps us drive more reality and organic growth for the product as well.
So back in November, you actually launched a brand campaign, uh, it's called "Friendship Pays," and so this had Will Ferrell as Mr. Monopoly.
It also had Chris Pratt, Kiki Palmer, and then the best hair guy of all time, Jason Mamoa.
So, in this campaign, you know, everyone knows that friendship is is a part of this, even though it's also about, you know, breaking alliances.
So, there's often this tension that happens between performance marketing and brand marketing.
I know all of you feel it.
Um, so, but you were crushing it in your way.
Absolutely winning.
How did you think about and conceptualizing?
Okay, now we want to do a brand campaign.
Yeah.
So we actually see this, we don't really think of brand campaigns.
We think more around how do we extend what we're already doing, and we think of it more 360.
So, um, I mean, first of all, you know, we didn't do this campaign for about 18 months after launch.
I'm a big believer for launch, community, creative, and UA do so much heavy lifting.
So think 360, everything, influencers, TV, connected TV, UA, it all worked together and was all part of the campaign.
We actually saw this as this is going to be like this thing that's going to last over a year, and we're going to build creative in a way that benefits UA, it benefits, uh, a social and Tik Tok, and we actually recorded, and by the way, Jason, wonderful guy, has great hair.
Um, but they were a lot of fun.
So we were trying to get things even with them authentically to record, you know, some things they were doing where they're talking to the camera and they're messing around, cuz we're like, that's not good for TV, that's fantastic for Tik Tok.
Thank you for sharing the secrets and and thank you to the marketing team behind this.
Um, you know, they often don't get all the credit.
The game team gets a lot of the credit.
So, I'm glad that we had a chance to hear a little bit more of of the story.
Awesome.
Cool.
Thanks for having me.
